thread.title: Legal help-line swamped by calls after woman's death
thread.title_full: Legal help-line swamped by calls after woman's death

author: Nance Haxton
title: Legal help-line swamped by calls after woman's death
text:
Map: Brisbane 4000 
A Queensland community legal centre has faced a surge in calls after a murder-suicide on the Gold Coast last week. 
Teresa Bradford was killed by her estranged husband David Bradford while he was out on bail on domestic violence charges. 
In the days after Ms Bradford's death, the Women's Legal Service Queensland helpline received 47 per cent more calls than usual from women concerned this could also happen to them. 
A recent surge in demand to the domestic violence helpline means that only half the calls can be answered. 
It comes as the Women's Legal Service braces for the impact of Federal Government funding cuts to community legal centres, which will take effect mid-2017. 
Coordinator Angela Lynch said the service was facing a crisis. 
"If we cannot help these women, if we cannot answer the call when they make that brave move to separate, then what are we talking about here?" 
The Women's Legal Service provides assistance to more than 11,000 women each year. 
Domestic violence survivor Rachael Moore said the legal service was extremely important. 
"We need people like the legal service that can actually come to your house, help you, go through a step by step process of how they're going to help you, what we can do," Ms Moore said. 
"First thing is you need to leave this house. Get out of the house you lived in with them." 
Ms Moore is only alive today because of the bravery of her five children who fought off her ex-partner after he shot her left arm at such close range that it was almost severed. 
She has had more than 15 major operations since her attack, but still faces the possibility her arm may have to be amputated. 
Ms Bradford's death has brought back the trauma of her experience nearly three years ago. 
"I've had periods, I don't talk about it a lot, but I've had months where I can't even leave the bed. It's hard. There's no-one there." Calls for public review of bail system 
Queensland's Attorney-General Yvette D'Ath has ordered an internal review of Queensland's bail system after it was revealed that Bradford was on bail when he murdered his wife and then took his own life. 
Offenders may be forced to prove why they should be released under the proposed changes. 
It has sparked concern that the review will not consult those affected by domestic violence. Family and domestic violence support services:
